section.title: Description
section.para: This course focuses on the development of a Java application data tier using the Java Persistence API (JPA). The course will introduce:

listitem.para: the role of the data tier
the basics of object/relational mapping using the JPA API
different means of querying (JPA-QL, Native, and Criteria)
deploying the JPA-based data tier server-side

section.para: The course is taught in the context of an overall JavaEE development. Eclipse and Maven are used to demonstrate techniques for building and testing data tier components. Weekly exercises are provided to give each student plenty of chances for hands-on work.

section.title: Course Objectives
section.para: This course will provide the student with the ability to design and implement a data tier using JPA and be able to identify pitfalls and implement optimized solutions.

listitem.para: Java development skills are required to actively complete the exercises.
Students should be prepared to spend between 2-4 hours a week outside of class.
"Pro JPA 2, 2nd Edition", Mike Keith and Merrick Schincariol, 2013, O'Reilly, ISBN-10: 1430249269; ISBN-13: 978-1430249269

section.title: Required Software
section.para: This course will make heavy use of development tools (Git, Maven 3, JUnit, Log4j, and Eclipse), a database (H2 Database Engine), and persistence provider (Hibernate). An application server (JBoss EAP 6/AS 7) will be part of the targeted deployment environment, but not central to the course concepts. Students are strongly encouraged to establish a local development environment. Detailed instructions for setup are part of the first exercise (Development Environment Setup).

section.title: References
section.para: The core of the JPA 2.1 content is covered in the primary text for the course (and competing texts as well as online). Associated topics (database schema, SQL, and tools) are not covered in the course text, but documentation will be provided through course slides, examples, and tutorials.

listitem.para: Attendance in five out of the six classes is required for credit
Make-up work is available and can be completed to receive credit for class(es) missed

section.title: Instructor Availability
section.para: I am available in the AM, before/after class, and evenings. I can conduct one-on-one webex sessions on class day and evenings. I do not have access to the Internet or SRA-net during the normal work day. I will check the e-mail and the class discussion group mornings, end-of-day, and evenings.

Note: I picked the end-of-day time for class to not have class smack in the middle of the day and allow you time to get to a useful location (or provide you an alternative activity to driving in rush-hour traffic).
